Name: n-Octacosane
Description: Octacosane is a straight-chain alkane containing 28 carbon atoms. It has a role as a plant metabolite.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) US Dept Agric; US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. 1992-2016. Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Octacosane. Available from, as of Jan 18, 2017: https://phytochem.nal.usda.gov/phytochem/search
plant_concentrations.Value: Octacosane detections in plants used in food and medicinal applications(1). /Octacosane/

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Al-Hassan JM et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 66: 646-52 (2001) (2) Pena E et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 57: 803-10 (1996) (3) Pena E et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 61: 72-9 (1998) (4) Pena E et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 63: 665-72 (1999)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Catfish samples collected from seven locations in the Arabian Gulf had concentrations of C28 alkanes (possibly octacosane) ranging from not detected to 3.3 ng/g wet weight(1). Mean (range) octacosane concentrations of 235.4 (151-441), 437.4 (not detected - 993) and 72.0 (not detected - 218) ng/g dry weight were reported in marine winkle (Osilinus attratus) samples collected from three sampling stations off the Coast of Tenerife (Canary Islands) during 1990-1991(2). Mean octacosane concentrations of 189.1, 63.62 and 150.0 ng/g dry weight were reported in intertidal limpet (Patella ulyssiponensis) from 3 sampling stations in the Canary Islands during 1991-1993(3). Mean octacosane concentrations of 967.3, 182.2, and 969.1 ng/g dry weight were reported in intertidal limpet (Patella crenata) collected during May 1991-December 1993 at 3 sampling stations in the Canary Islands(4).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Hori et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83: 455-61 (2009)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Octacosane concentrations were 10-297 ng/g dry weight in sediments samples collected from 14 sites from the Shinano River in Niigata, Japan from November 2005 to April 2006(1).
